title: Simple Scones Recipe
description: These buttery scones are soft, tender, and easy to make with simple baking ingredients for the perfect addition to breakfast, brunch, or afternoon tea.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Bread Quick Bread Recipes Scone Recipes Simple Scones 4.9 (3,064) 2,481 Reviews 649 Photos Delicious tender scones with juicy raisins. This sweet scone recipe is easy to make with simple baking ingredients, butter, and sour cream. Perfect for a holiday breakfast, brunch, or afternoon treat with a cup of tea! Submitted by USA WEEKEND columnist Pam Anderson Updated on April 7, 2025 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 649 649 649 649 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 15 mins Additional Time: 5 mins Total Time: 35 mins Servings: 8 Yield: 8 scones Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe These scones are easy to make the next time you need to impress your family or guests. This aptly named recipe is proof that anyone can bake like a pro! How to Make Scones You'll find the full, step-by-step recipe below — but here's a brief overview of what you can expect when you make these homemade scones: Mix the dry ingredients, then work the butter into the dough using your fingers.Add the raisins.Whisk the sour cream and egg together.Stir the egg mixture into the flour mixture.Transfer the dough to a floured surface and pat into a circle.Sprinkle the dough with sugar and cut it into triangles.Bake the scones in a preheated oven until golden brown. Cook’s Note Mix it up with one of these variations on the basic scone recipe:For Cranberry-Orange Scones: Add a generous teaspoon of finely grated orange zest to the dry ingredients and substitute dried cranberries for the raisins.For Lemon-Blueberry Scones: Add a generous teaspoon of finely grated lemon zest to the dry ingredients and substitute dried blueberries for the raisins.For Cherry-Almond Scones: Add 1/2 teaspoon almond extract to the sour cream mixture and substitute dried cherries for the raisins. How to Store and Freeze Scones Store the simple scones in an airtight container at room temperature for up to two days or in the fridge for up to one week. You can freeze the scones for up to three months. Thaw in the refrigerator overnight or at room temperature for a few hours. Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise  "Great and easy recipe," according to one Allrecipes community member. "I used almond flour and no fat Greek yogurt as substitutes and it came out really good!" "This is my go-to scone recipe and I don't think I'll find one that's any better," says noahjr1980.  "This is a great recipe," says Mary Blubaugh. "Super easy and the scone is moist … not dry at all. It's the perfect 'base' recipe. I will be making all the variations!" Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings 2 cups all-purpose flour ⅓ cup sugar 1 teaspoon baking powder ½ teaspoon salt ¼ teaspoon baking soda 8 tablespoons unsalted butter, frozen ½ cup raisins or dried currants ½ cup sour cream 1 large egg 1 teaspoon white sugar Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C); adjust the oven rack to the lower-middle position. Line a baking tray with parchment paper. Mix flour, 1/3 cup sugar, baking powder, salt, and baking soda in a medium bowl. Grate butter into flour mixture on the large holes of a box grater. Use your fingers to work in butter until mixture resembles coarse crumbs, then toss in raisins. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Whisk sour cream and egg together in a small bowl until combined. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Stir sour cream mixture into flour mixture using a fork until large dough clumps form. Use your hands to shape dough into a ball. (Dough may seem dry at first but will come together as you work it.) Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place dough on a lightly floured surface and pat into a 7 to 8-inch circle, about 3/4-inch thick. Sprinkle with remaining 1 teaspoon of sugar. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Use a sharp knife to cut into 8 equal triangles; place on the prepared baking tray, about 1-inch apart. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bake scones in the preheated oven until golden, about 15 to 17 minutes. Cool for 5 minutes; serve warm or at room temperature. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Serve and enjoy! Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 4,710 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Simple Scones 01 of 649 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 649 Photo by  Susan DeRuyter 02/13/2025 Super easy for my first time making scones! I used my food processor until it was time to form the dough into a ball. It made it really easy with the frozen butter. It'll be fun to experiment with different add-ins! 03 of 649 Photo by  Sir Bilbo Baggins 01/06/2025 I used fresh cranberries placed on top and grated orange zest in the dough. I knew the fresh cranberries would not "bake into the dough" and was fine with that. Otherwise I followed the instructions as intended. Using the measured ingredients, my dough would not come together at all, after several minutes of hand mixing. The frozen butter was starting to melt. It is very dry in our climate currently, and I believe the size "large" eggs at the store are slightly smaller than previous normal sizes. Maybe these factors were affecting the mix? Anyways the mix was too dry to come together. I added an extra quarter cup of sour cream just to bring the dough together. And refrigerated the dough for 10 minutes just to bring the temperature back down again.I started with 15 minutes of baking and they were raw in the middle. Ended up baking the second batch for 20 minutes. Extra time needed was probably due to added extra moisture.The final result is a very heavy stodgy scone. I was hoping these would be light because of the shredded butter. 04 of 649 Photo by  Rach the Rad 12/26/2024 5 stars for taste, 4 stars for process. I’ve seen reviews discussing how melting the butter doesn’t affect the end product or how it’s beneficial to add an egg. I might try one or both of these methods because my only complaint is that I’ve usually struggled to get the dough to stick together (I’ve made this recipe several times!). I added more sour cream once and that helped.However, the end result is delectable. Soo soft and tasty with the perfect amount of sweetness! I’ve made with raisins, but I’ve also made the lemon blueberry and the cranberry orange iterations. Everyone loves them!I’ve found that these are best the day they’re made. I’ve also frozen the finished product, and it doesn’t seem to maintain its soft texture after freezing. So I wouldn’t personally recommend freezing the end result (the prebaked batter might be different). 05 of 649 Photo by  ballooning64 11/03/2024 I made these with Craisins, a bit less sugar, and used my Cuisinart to blend everything. These turned out lovely...fluffy, and delish. Would definitely use this recipe again. 06 of 649 Photo by  fabeveryday 03/23/2024 Made these exactly as described and it was perfect! 07 of 649 Photo by  FeistyPho1387 02/24/2024 A keeper! Easy to follow Crowd-pleaser Family favorite This is an excellent, easy to follow recipe for delicious scones. Freezing and grating the butter is the key to the deliciously flaky texture. I’ve modified as follows: 1 cup fruit (raisins, currants, dried cranberries or frozen blueberries); 1/4 c. sour cream and 1/4 c. 1/2 & 1/2 cream for a perfect result. Enjoy! 08 of 649 Photo by  IcySauce7509 01/30/2024 A keeper! Easy to follow My first time making this delicious and super simple recipe, I marinated the grapes and added orange zest, and add some of the same marinade liquor, and egg brush on top. 09 of 649 Photo by  MirthDosa2572 11/19/2023 I made this for my children and they freaking loved them. I also used a pizza cutter to get the perfect triangle. 10 of 649 Photo by  SCOOTER FARNSWORTH 11/06/2023 Very easy recipe. I made the cran orange scones with fresh zest and dried orange peel.
